instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
customer brought it in, no liquid damage, I got green light on charger
it can turn on, normally, after a few minutes of use, it will suddenly shut down
tried with booting from usb drive, still sudden dead
after a bit of testing and trying, its life slowly lessened, it will only boot to login screen, and then poof dead
after that, it only boot to apple halfway and then dead, and after that, it can't even be turn on anymore
I have tried reballing smc, still the same

is this pch problem ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
Check if starts in SMC bypass mode first.
If not, post some voltages and signals for power on sequence.
Don't forget to check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
smc bypass does nothing
17/18 : 3 ohm
27/28 : 20 ohm
compared to working board, seems normal

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42 v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> : 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is 0.6v
if s4 doesnt even come, no need to check <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> stuff etc right ?

if i <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> , <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> doesnt go low
i have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
processor is getting warm, fan ocassionally twitching

update : i have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> at 3.3v, but keep cycling on and off every few second

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
If you get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, then you must get some S3 and S0 voltages; maybe not VCORE.
So check if VCORE pulses at least.
Check if board stays on without RAM.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V, doesnt even pulse..
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> resistance to ground is 2.6 ohm, is that normal ?
i don't know what do you mean by board stay on, it doesnt even turned on, or do you mean the green light ?

by the value of the voltage, can i assume at least the smc is not the problem ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
AXG and VCORE are very low values as normal for Ivy Bridge CPU.

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> doesnt go low"
Must stay high when board is turned on.
It should go off if you maintain power button pressed 4s.

"i have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>"
So secondary power supplies controled by this signal can be on; check that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> doesnt go low even after holding <SIGNAL>SMCONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
Sorry i don understand <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> instruction..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
""i have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>"
So secondary power supplies controled by this signal can be on; check that."
Which is the exact level of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>?
Check all the secondary power supplies enabled by this signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
this customer change battery before, but come back after 1 week for sudden shutdown issue
he doesnt want to wait anymore so i refund him his money, got a little mad because its completely dead now,
you can closed this thread, but i just want to ask, how do you prevent or handle situation like this ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly shutdown
threads.message:
You need different voltage readings to diagnose the board.
Could be a problem generated by fake chinese battery...
